name: Boston
fun_fact: Fun fact: Union Oyster House, America's oldest continuously operating restaurant (since 1826), started serving clam chowder in 1836 and now serves over 10,000 gallons per year. Boston pioneered cream-based 'New England' clam chowder, building on Indigenous peoples' clear broth-style chowders that date back hundreds of years.

hero_dishes.name: New England Clam Chowder
hero_dishes.description: A thick, creamy white soup made with fresh quahog clams, diced potatoes, salt pork or bacon, and rich cream. The hallmarks are sacrosanct: milky-white creamy base, chopped clams, diced potatoes.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Indigenous tribes in Massachusetts made clear broth-style chowders with quahogs (local clams) hundreds of years ago. English settlers incorporated their traditions, swapping corn and beans for potatoes. By 1751, a recipe appeared in a Boston newspaper. Union Oyster House began serving it in 1836, cementing Boston as the chowder capital.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Union Oyster House (oldest, 10,000+ gallons/year), Atlantic Fish Company (bread bowl version, Back Bay), Yankee Lobster Company (family-owned Seaport gem), James Hook & Co (2-time Boston Chowder Fest champs), Neptune Oyster

hero_dishes.name: Lobster Roll
hero_dishes.description: Fresh lobster meat dressed lightly with mayonnaise, served in a toasted, buttered New England-style split-top bun. Can be served cold (mayo-based) or warm (butter-based).
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born from Boston's coastal heritage and fishing traditions, lobster rolls celebrate the simplicity and freshness of New England seafood. The split-top bun design allows for maximum lobster-to-bread ratio.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Luke's Lobster Back Bay, Neptune Oyster, Yankee Lobster Company, James Hook & Co (Seaport District)

signature_drinks.name: Sam Adams Boston Lager
signature_drinks.description: Boston's iconic craft beer, brewed locally since 1984. A Vienna-style lager with rich amber color and balanced malt-hop flavor.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with seafood, especially clam chowder and lobster rolls. Available at nearly every Boston restaurant and often enjoyed during Red Sox games at Fenway Park.

food_culture_notes: Boston's seafood culture reflects its deep fishing heritage - the city has been a maritime hub since colonial times
Chowder has 'been part of Boston culture for a long time and represents what New England is. It's a hearty, simple dish' (Chef Jeremy Sewall)
The Seaport District has transformed into a bustling food destination while maintaining authentic fishing traditions
Boston cannoli in the North End (Little Italy) are another iconic treat, especially from Mike's Pastry and Modern Pastry
Faneuil Hall Marketplace and Quincy Market offer concentrated food experiences with many local vendors

landmarks: Red brick buildings of Back Bay
atmosphere: Maritime blue and white color schemes
unique_modern: Family-owned seafood shacks in modern Seaport
Bread bowl presentations at contemporary restaurants
